citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee is treating a Pomeranian Puppy with an unknown antibiotic. At the time of inspection, the puppy appears to
be in good health. This puppy was seen by the attending veterinarian and prescribed amoxi drops to be given twice a day
until sold. The bottle of the medicine being used is in amoxicillin bottle with an expiration date of December-2022 and also
has a fish-mox label on it, both are 250 mg/5 mL concentrations. The licensee believes this medicine to be amoxicillin, the
inspector cannot be sure of what medicine is contained in the bottle. When the inspector contacted the attending
veterinarian, he stated he prescribed Amoxi-drops twice a day and a facility representative stated to the veterinarian they
had some at the facility to use. The veterinarian did not authorize the use of Fish-Mox or expired amoxicillin for this dog.
The use of an unapproved medicine or an expired medicine does not ensure the medical condition is being appropriately
treated and that the puppy is receiving adequate veterinary care.
The licensee must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee
must obtain the appropriate medication from a licensed veterinarian and follow the attending veterinarian’s care
instructions.
To be corrected by: 24-February-2023.

The licensee is not following the Program of Veterinary Care’s head-to-tail adult dog exam schedule. The Program of
Veterinary Care states all adult dogs will be examined "at least annually, with 25% of adults examined quarterly." The
licensee was due for these exams to take place in January 2023 according to this schedule, but the exams have not taken
place and they have not made the appointment at the time of inspection. Failure to follow to head-to-tail exam schedule
for adult dogs does not ensure adequate veterinary care and oversight of the attending veterinarian.
Each dealer must keep, maintain and follow a written Program of Veterinary Care which includes a complete physical
examination from head-to-tail of each adult dog by the attending veterinarian not less than once every 12 months or as
often as the Attending Veterinarian and licensee have agreed to. The licensee must ensure that the adult dogs have the
head-to-tail exams done as often as the schedule on the Program of Veterinary Care instructs but no less than every 12
months.
To be corrected by: 10-March-2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
The licensee was verbally instructed of the correction dates during the exit interview on 22-February-2023.
End Section

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee is treating a Pomeranian Puppy with an unknown antibiotic. At the time of inspection, the puppy appears to 
be in good health. This puppy was seen by the attending veterinarian and prescribed amoxi drops to be given twice a day 
until sold. The bottle of the medicine being used is in amoxicillin bottle with an expiration date of December-2022 and also 
has a fish-mox label on it, both are 250 mg/5 mL concentrations. The licensee believes this medicine to be amoxicillin, the 
inspector cannot be sure of what medicine is contained in the bottle. When the inspector contacted the attending 
veterinarian, he stated he prescribed Amoxi-drops twice a day and a facility representative stated to the veterinarian they 
had some at the facility to use. The veterinarian did not authorize the use of Fish-Mox or expired amoxicillin for this dog. 
The use of an unapproved medicine or an expired medicine does not ensure the medical condition is being appropriately 
treated and that the puppy is receiving adequate veterinary care. 
The licensee must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee 
must obtain the appropriate medication from a licensed veterinarian and follow the attending veterinarian’s care 
instructions. 
To be corrected by: 24-February-2023. 
3.13(a)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs.

The licensee is not following the Program of Veterinary Care’s head-to-tail adult dog exam schedule. The Program of 
Veterinary Care states all adult dogs will be examined "at least annually, with 25% of adults examined quarterly." The 
licensee was due for these exams to take place in January 2023 according to this schedule, but the exams have not taken 
place and they have not made the appointment at the time of inspection. Failure to follow to head-to-tail exam schedule 
for adult dogs does not ensure adequate veterinary care and oversight of the attending veterinarian. 
Each dealer must keep, maintain and follow a written Program of Veterinary Care which includes a complete physical 
examination from head-to-tail of each adult dog by the attending veterinarian not less than once every 12 months or as 
often as the Attending Veterinarian and licensee have agreed to. The licensee must ensure that the adult dogs have the 
head-to-tail exams done as often as the schedule on the Program of Veterinary Care instructs but no less than every 12 
months. 
To be corrected by: 10-March-2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
The licensee was verbally instructed of the correction dates during the exit interview on 22-February-2023. 
 
End Section
